definitions.definition: to make a determined effort to deal with a difficult problem or situation

examples.text: The government is determined to tackle inflation.
I think I'll tackle the repairs next weekend.
Firefighters tackled a blaze in a garage last night.
The drugs problem has to be tackled head-on.
The problem is being tackled with a range of measures.
We are failing to tackle the key issues.

definitions.definition: to speak to somebody about a problem or difficult situation

examples.text: I tackled him about the money he owed me.

definitions.definition: to try and take the ball from an opponent

examples.text: He was tackled just outside the penalty area.

definitions.definition: to make an opponent fall to the ground in order to stop them running

examples.text: He can run fast and tackle hard.

definitions.definition: to deal with somebody who is violent or threatening you

examples.text: He tackled a masked intruder at his home.

wordOrigin: Middle English (denoting equipment for a specific task): probably from Middle Low German takel, from taken ‘lay hold of’. Early senses of the verb (late Middle English) described the provision and handling of a ship's equipment.
